topic.title: Release notes
topic.abstract: Couchbase Server 3.0 is a major release that extends Couchbase lead as the most performant and scalable NoSQL database for mission critical enterprise applications. In addition to adding great new functionality for the enterprise, 3.0 delivers many new features that make it easier for developers and administrators to work with Couchbase Server, making it the best choice for your NoSQL projects.

body.p: Couchbase Server 3.0.2, released in December 2014, is the second maintenance release for Couchbase Server 3.0. This release further fortifies Couchbase Server 3.0 and includes some critical bug fixes in the areas of database engine, performance, security, and server operations. It also includes several bug fixes related to the Windows platform.

section.title: Fixed issues in 3.0.2
section.p: The following issues are fixed in the Couchbase Server 3.0.2 release.

row.entry: Issue
Description
Couchbase bucket
When a key is locked, setWithMeta() is able to update the key even when the set fails.
memcached was crashing during the online upgrade from the Couchbase Server version 2.5.0 to version 3.0.1.
gethrtime() implementation on Windows can cause requests to store() with CAS to be incorrectly processed.
Performance
Access log locks for heavy write workloads can cause performance slowdowns.
Massive increase in disk write queue size on both SSD and HDD was detected.
Security
A number of CAPI REST API endpoints is not secured.
XDCR crash logs can sometimes have document contents.
Corrupted key in a data file rolls backwards to an earlier version, or disappears without detection.
The XDCR-over-SSL proxy allows for a connection to any port on the destination nodes.
Remove support for SSL v3 in ns_server SSL server sockets to mitigate against the POODLE attack.
Configuration replication of certain per-node keys is broken after a node is upgraded offline from 2.x to 3.0 and then added back to formerly 2.x cluster that is now upgraded to 3.0.
Certain XDCR logging exposes remote cluster passwords.
Server operations
Failed connections on port 11213 cause Unable to listen errors and server restarts.
Race condition with time check when changing the data path may lead to deletion of all buckets after adding a node to a cluster.
Offline cluster upgrade failed when upgrading from 2.0.1-170-rel to 3.0.1-1422-rel.
In an XDCR environment, when add-delete-add operations are performed, the second add operation fails when performed on temporary items.
Windows
memcached.logs can grow large after the node failure and bucket flush.
Compact files might not be cleaned up after compaction.
View engine failed to index documents in a query after the rebalance.
Incremental backup must not consume additional space with no delta.
Online upgrade from 2.0.0 to 3.0.1 with a single bucket might fail warmup.
An infinite timeout on the outgoing xmem request might lead to XDCR hanging when there are network or NAT issues.

section.title: Known issues in 3.0.2
section.p: The following known issues are associated with Couchbase Server release 3.0.2.

row.entry: Issue
Description
Security
Remove support for SSL v3 in memcached SSL server sockets to mitigate against the POODLE attack.

section.note: Port scanners might detect that port 11207 negotiates SSLv3. Upgrading to the latest 2.x client SDKs blocks pre-TLS communication and reduces the risk of the POODLE bug.

body.p: Couchbase Server 3.0.1, released in October 2014, is the first maintenance release for Couchbase Server 3.0. This release focuses on getting the system stability bugs fixed for the Windows platform and providing general availability. In addition, this release includes some critical bug fixes related to meta data corruption.

section.title: Fixed issues in 3.0.1
section.p: The following issues are fixed in the Couchbase Server 3.0.1 release.

row.entry: Issue
Description
Couchbase bucket
Could not recreate the default bucket after deleting it.
After warmup, fewer items are shown.
Memcached error #132 Internal error: Internal error for vbucket... when set key to bucket.
Installation

Once installation of the Couchbase Server is completed, it launches a console page that opens with a blank page.
Failed to load Beer Sample in the initial setup.
Rebalance

The offline upgrade from 2.5.x to 3.0.1 failed.
All data was lost after an offline upgrade from 2.0.0 to 3.0.0.
Views

section.title: Known issues in 3.0.1
section.p: The following issues are associated with Couchbase Server release 3.0.1.

row.entry: Issue
Description
Database operations

In situations with high throughput (when the client is making multiple parallel requests), or with very low network latency (such as when running on localhost), there is a high probability that requests to store() with CAS might incorrectly be processed on the Windows Server due to the change in gethrtime() implementation. It is recommended that Windows users stay on version 2.5.x, or wait for the next maintenance release 3.0.2.
Performance
Regression (from 2.5.1) in rebalance out with views and query workload.
Regression (from 2.5.1) in rebalance after failover with views and query workload.
Regression in 4 to 3 node rebalance out on the Windows 2012 Server.
Upgrade

Replication of certain per-node keys is broken after a node is first upgraded offline from 2.x to 3.0 and then added back to the formerly 2.x cluster that is now upgraded to 3.0.
Workaround: When performing an online upgrade from Couchbase Server 2.x to 3.x, always fully delete the 2.x package (including the config files) before installing the 3.x package.
Data lost with online upgrade from 2.0.0 to 3.0.1 and cluster reboot.

section.note: Couchbase is working on known issues related to performance and upgrading on the Windows platform. When upgrading to the Couchbase Server Windows 3.0.1 release, test your applications extensively before upgrading. Couchbase also requires that you upgrade to the latest available production version before upgrading to Couchbase Server 3.0.1. For Enterprise Edition customers, that version is Couchbase Server 2.5.1. For Community Edition users, that version is Couchbase Server 2.2.0.

body.p: Couchbase Server 3.0, released in September 2014, includes many major new enhancements and features:

li.p: This feature allows you to run at planet scale with more data, faster I/O, and improved indexing.

ul.li: Tunable memory lets you configure memory to optimize meta data, data caching and eviction strategies, allowing configurations ranging from full in-memory database to large disk-based datasets.
Shared thread pool per node delivers high I/O throughput and low latency for data reads, writes, and other operations such as database warm-up.
Stream-based views based on Database Change Protocol (DCP), a new streaming protocol, reduce latency for view updates, and provide faster view consistency and fresher data.

li.p: This feature provides highly available applications with faster and easier data replication across multiple data centers, and advanced disaster recovery options.

ul.li: Stream-based XDCR (Cross Data Center Replication) lowers XDCR latency using memory-to-memory replication of data from the source cluster to the destination cluster, even before it reaches the disk.
Delta-node recovery permits that nodes be quickly added back after they are repaired, so they can catch up incrementally from where they left off.
Incremental backup and restore enables administrators to quickly back up only modified data in the database, making the backup more efficient for larger datasets.

li.p: This feature provides secure on-the-wire data access for applications and administrators.

ul.li: Encrypted admin access enables HTTPS access for the Couchbase admin console and the REST API.
Encrypted data access with SSL encrypts data in-flight between client and server.

li.p: This feature provides easy cluster management and resource governance.

ul.li: Pause and resume XDCR enables XDCR streams between source and destination clusters to be paused during maintenance windows and resumed later, continuing from where they left off.
Graceful failover enables nodes to be safely removed from the cluster after all in-flight operations are completed.
Bucket priority enables prioritization of buckets so that additional I/O resources can be assigned to the higher priority buckets for faster workload execution.
Cluster-wide diagnostics is provided for improved cluster management.

section.title: Couchbase .NET incompatibility
section.p: An incompatibility between Microsoft Framework 4.0 or earlier, the Couchbase .NET SDK 1.3.7 or earlier, and Couchbase Server 3.0 has been identified where the URL generated for a View operation on the Couchbase bucket is improperly encoded. This causes view requests to fail with the following message in the body:

dlentry.dd: The affected Microsoft .NET versions are 4.0 or earlier, Couchbase .NET SDK 1.3.7 or earlier, and Couchbase Server 3.0 (including Beta) is >= 3.0.

Microsoft .NET version 4.5 changes the way Uri.ToString handles its Unicode encoding, which resolves the issue. In this case, clients running on this version or higher of the CLR are not impacted. Additionally, Couchbase Server 2.5 and lower are not impacted. Couchbase .NET 1.3.8 has a patch that resolves the issue for all versions of Couchbase Server and Microsoft .NET Frameworks.

In addition to the patch released with Couchbase .NET SDK version 1.3.8, add the following element to your App.Config or Web.Config to enable support for all SDK and Server versions:<uri> <iriParsing enabled="true"/> <uri>
Customers who are not ready or cannot upgrade their Couchbase .NET SDKs to 1.3.8 or greater are strongly advised to add this element to their deployments if they intend to use the Couchbase .NET SDK with Couchbase Server 3.0 or greater.

section.title: Views behavior change
section.p: The stale=false view query argument has been enhanced. It considers all document changes that have been received at the time the query was received. This means it is no longer needed to use the durability requirements or the Observe feature to block for persistence in application code before issuing the stale=false stale query. It is recommended that you remove all such application level checks after completing the upgrade to the 3.0 release.

section.title: Fixed issues in 3.0.0
section.p: There are many bugs fixed in the 3.0.0 release. Some of the notable fixes include the following:

row.entry: Issue
Description
Couchbase bucket
Replica vbucket simply ignores the rev_seq values of new items from the active vbucket.
High replication latency is observed due to the racing in pausing and resuming of the TAP connection notifier.
Warmup with an access log always sets the loaded document's rev-id to 1.
Views
File descriptor leak is detected in views with reduce.
V8 crashes on memory allocation errors and closes Erlang on some indexing loads .

section.title: Known issues in 3.0.0
section.p: The following known issues are associated with Couchbase Server release 3.0.0:

row.entry: Issue
Description
DCP/rebalance
Rebalance operation hung during the online upgrade.
Rebalance swap regression of 39.3% when compared with release 2.5.1.
Rebalance after failover, 3 to 4 nodes regression of 54.9% when compared with 2.5.1.
Intra-replication falling far behind under moderate to heavy workload when XDCR is enabled on the small-scale hardware (for example, AWS instances).
Views
One node is slow, possibly due to the Erlang scheduler.
Sliding endseqno during initial index build or DCP reading from disk snapshot results in longer stale=false query latency and index start-up time.
